thread.title: Pence's defense comes up in Russian meddling story
thread.title_full: Pence's defense comes up in Russian meddling story

author: indystar.com
title: Pence's defense comes up in Russian meddling story
text:
President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence walk on the South Driveway of the White House to greet Harley Davidson executives and union representatives, Feb. 2, 2017. (Photo: MICHAEL REYNOLDS, EPA)
189 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 4 COMMENT EMAIL MORE A story in The Washington Post raises questions about Vice President Mike Pence 's comments defending communications between an adviser to President Donald Trump and a Russian diplomat.
The Post, citing unnamed current and former U.S. officials, reported Thursday that Trump's national security adviser Michael Flynn privately discussed U.S. sanctions against Russia with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak.
The new revelations contradict statements Pence made last month, five days before he was sworn in as vice president.
"I talked to Gen. Flynn about that conversation," Pence told CBS' John Dickerson on Jan. 15. “They did not discuss anything having to do with the United States’ decision to expel diplomats or impose censure against Russia.”
The Post story pokes holes in Pence's comments, but does not address whether Pence knew all the details when he defended Flynn in the interview in that interview. One source told the Post that Pence may have been misled or misspoke.
Some U.S. officials called the communications between Flynn and Kislyak inappropriate and possibly illegal when they came to light last month, the Post reported.
National security adviser Michael Flynn privately discussed U.S. sanctions against Russia with that country’s ambassador to the United States during the month before President Trump took office, contrary to public assertions by Trump officials, current and former U.S. officials said.
Flynn’s communications with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak were interpreted by some senior U.S. officials as an inappropriate and potentially illegal signal to the Kremlin that it could expect a reprieve from sanctions that were being imposed by the Obama administration in late December to punish Russia for its alleged interference in the 2016 election.
Flynn on Wednesday denied that he had discussed sanctions with Kislyak. Asked in an interview whether he had ever done so, he twice said, “No.”
